div.head: “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”
Title
div.p: In the earlier of two surviving fair copies of the poem (see Manuscripts), RF T70, Ruskin centered “THE CONSTELLATIONS” above the column of lines. Then, in what appears an afterthought, he added “NORTHERN” to the right in the margin, on the baseline of the main title; and on a second line below “NORTHERN”, placed awkwardly in the margin to the right of the opening lines of the poem, he added “SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”. The added, trailing subtitle suggests that he extended the title as he expanded the poem, perhaps revealing one reason why he gave up on this fair copy, RF T70, revised some of its lines on the same copy (see Composition and Publication), and made a new fair copy incorporating these changes.

In the second surviving fair copy, in MS III, Ruskin incorporated his revisions to the first fair copy, including allowing space to center the subtitle properly below the main title and above the first line, breaking the three lines as “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”.
The fragment of draft of the poem, which is bound in MS IA, is untitled, since the surviving pages begin with lines from the middle of the poem.
See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Catalogue poem.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: In MS IA, one item consisting of a vertically folded sheet contains untitled draft written in pencil on three sides.

A facsimile in the form of a photograph held by The Ruskin, RF T70, is the only known record of a manuscript containing a fair copy in ink print lettering, which Ruskin revised in a cursive hand on the same sheet, using both pencil and ink. The photograph apparently was taken during preparation of the Library Edition, but unused.

Ruskinʼs revisions to RF T70 are incorporated into a fair copy contained in MS III, as the first poem in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology; hence, this version ranks chronologically as the second known fair copy. MS III is a Red Book, which begins with “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, a work that likewise reflects an interest in astronomy (see Discussion).

div.head: Date
div.p: Cook and Wedderburn ascribe the poem to 1827, citing MS IA and MS III (Works, 2:535). They do not mention the manuscript that they apparently knew at some point in time from the photograph, RF T70, which is presently catalogued among transcripts made for the Library Edition. The editorsʼ dating, judging by their only other mention of the poem, was based on an association of its fragment of rough draft with another fragment rough draft, similar in appearance, of “The Monastery” (Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1). They bound both fragments in MS IA.

There is no question that the earliest surviving manuscript is the MS IA draft, which was the basis for the fair copy photographed as RF T70, which in turn was the basis for the MS III fair copy (see Composition and Publication). Internal evidence suggests that Ruskin may have based the first lines of the poem on actual observation of the sky. The alignment of planets and constellations described at the beginning of the poem would have been observable in April–May 1828, but not at all in 1827 (see Discussion). Physical evidence of both fair‐copy manuscripts, moreover, strongly suggests a date in 1828. The question is whether composition of the draft could have begun in 1827.

None of the three manuscripts is dated in Ruskinʼs hand. Of the three, the fair copy in MS III can most convincingly be dated 1828. Its placement in the Red Book following “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2” and preceding “The Sun”, both of which were completed for New Yearʼs 1828, indicates some point of time after 1 January 1828 for this copy of “The Constellations”. By placing the poem first in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology, immediately following “Harry and Lucy”, Ruskin appears to emphasize a thematic association between the poem and the prose tale, in which Harry gives Lucy a drawing of Charlesʼs Wain “as an introduction to astronomy”. It is unknown, however, how much time lapsed between fair‐copying of “Harry and Lucy” and compilation of the poetry anthology, so the the poem's placement in the latter, prior to the New Yearʼs poem “The Sun”, does not necessarily argue for composition in the preceding year, 1827.

A factor that would confine a parameter for composition to the first quarter of 1828 is the possibility that certain details were dependent on actual observation of the sky (see Discussion: Observations Actual and Poetic). Those details occur in the opening lines of the poem as fair‐copied; and since those lines are missing from the MS IA draft, the possible real‐life factor cannot be applied. Therefore, an earlier genesis of the poem cannot be ruled out, with initial composition of the MS IA draft commencing sometime in the second half of 1827, and the first fair copy, RF T70, being produced in winter leading up to New Yearʼs 1828. In that scenario, the first fair copy succumbed to revision, and the second fair copy was inscribed into MS III, perhaps sometime in the first quarter of 1828.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: A single line quoted in Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1. Poem previously unpublished in entirety.

From surviving documents, a clear chronology is established based on revisions of one document being incorporated in the next. Strikethroughs and substitutions in the MS IA pencil draft contribute to the base text of the fair copy shown in RF T70; and strikethroughs and substitutions in the latter are incorporated into copytext for the MS III fair copy (see Textual Glosses for the three witnesses). This genetic history tracks a similar record of Ruskinʼs development of the poem, “The Monastery”.

As a stage of development in Ruskinʼs compositional methods, “The Constellations” along with “The Monastery” represent a significant advance since he learned to use pen and ink in April 1827 (see The Ruskin Family Handwriting). For the first time, we see revised draft containing deletions, substitutions, and insertions, both in pencil and in ink. It is possible that the MS IA draft manuscripts only seem to bear witness to a maturing process of revision because they happen to have been preserved, whereas draft manuscript of earlier works may have been discarded or existed in a more ephemeral form such as slate writing. It is equally possible, however, that the MS IA draft was preserved because it bears witness to new revision process. The RF T70 manuscript is even unique in exhibiting a fair copy that was sacrificed to revision on the same document.

The poem is also significant for its scope, as one of several ambitious projects of 1828, including the versification of Scottʼs novel, The Monastery, and the “poem on the universe”, Eudosia. Of the three, only “The Constellations” reached a conclusion.

div.head: MS IA Draft
div.p: The item of draft in MS IA is a fragment, in a penciled cursive hand, starting at line 27 and extending to line 64 of the poem as completed in the MS III fair—copy version. The draft text includes deletions in the form of strikethroughs, and substitutions above or following the deletions, using both pen and pencil for the changes. The manuscript clearly is missing its original opening lines, beginning as it does at the top of 1r in mid—career of the poem, lacking title or context. (It is possible that the missing piece of the draft manuscript of “Constellations” did once exist as originally bound; see MS IA: Contents, b). The draft also lacks lines found at the ends of the two fair copies. Unlike the missing opening lines, however, the final lines, which fall on 2r of the manuscript, evidently served as the original conclusion, since Ruskin noted (in ink, and using a smaller script) “I end end” below and to the left of the final line. In RF T70, the poem continues beyond the final lines as drafted for another nine lines, and in MS III for another fourteen lines.

The appearance of this manuscript is strikingly similar—in its sprawling pencil cursive and its smaller ink cursive hands, as well as in its paper and size of the physical document—to an item of draft of “The Monastery”, which begins “now must we leave poor martin there”, and which contains lines 29–62 of book 2 of Ruskinʼs versification of Scottʼs novel as those lines are fair—copied and numbered in MS III. This leaf of draft likewise was bound in MS IA. As remarked in the compositional history of “The Monastery”, the episode of Scottʼs plot narrated in this passage describes how the Englishman, Captain Stawarth Bolton, offers to adopt the two sons of the Scottish widow, Elspet Glendinning—Edward, the younger, and Halbert, the elder. Because this stage of draft and fair copy are ascribed (based on physical evidence) to 1828, it can be argued that Ruskinʼs selection of this episode reflects a preoccupation with the permanent adoption of his cousin, Mary Richardson, into the Herne Hill household following the death of her widowed mother, Jessie Richardson (see “The Monastery”: Composition and Publication—Stage One of Composition; “The Monastery”: Discussion—The Family Context of Composition). Ruskin perhaps cemented composition of “The Constellations” onto this family drama, which underlay composition of “The Monastery”. In “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, which precedes “The Constellations” in MS III, Harry offers to give Lucy “a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”, Lucy assenting that “she would like it very much”. Thus, Ruskin situates the avatar of his cousin in his paper world of text. (In terms of dating, the influence of this family drama does not necessarily confine composition to 1828 since, prior to her motherʼs death in that year, Mary was already resident to a limited extent at Herne Hill in 1827, although at that time enrolled in a boarding school.)

div.div:
Fist Fair Copy (RF T70)
Physical similarities connect composition of “The Constellations” with “The Monastery” not only in the cursive pencil hand and writing surfaces used for their drafts, but also in
shared eccentricities of ink print lettering used for their fair—copy manuscripts.
The treatment of text in books 1–2 of “The Monastery”, as fair—copied in MS III, has more in common with “The Constellations”, as fair—copied in RF T70, than it does with what immediately precedes the “Monastery” poem in MS III—the 1827 anthology, “poetry discriptive”—or even with books 3–4 of “The Monastery”, which are set apart from books 1–2 in MS III (see “The Monastery”: Composition and Publication—Stage One of Composition). For the poems in “poetry discriptive”, Ruskin formed large, spindly characters with pen and ink, which he had learned to use recently, in April 1827, whereas he adopted a comparatively miniscule print—lettering, more like a serif book type for the “Monastery”, 1–2, and “Constellations”, RF T70. Moreover, in the earlier 1827 works, he almost entirely avoided punctuation, whereas punctuation does characterize the fair copies of “Constellations”, RF T70, and “Monastery”, 1–2; and the punctuation marks are distinctively obsessive and eccentric. Almost every line of books 1–2 of “The Monastery” is punctuated, regardless of need grammatically and rhetorically, and the marks are used only at the ends of lines. This obsessive observance abruptly ceases at book 2, line 80, at the top of page 79. Just so, the end of every line of the RF T70 “Constellations” is notched with a punctuation mark until line 20, where the practice abruptly stops. Where used, the punctuation marks often seem arbitrary: while the full—stop periods usually make grammatical sense, the commas, colons, and (in “The Monastery”) an upside—down semicolon seem interchangeable. It appears, therefore, that Ruskin layered over these texts with bookish punctuation to give the appearance of print, without entirely understanding the function of various marks—until he tired of the process and stopped altogether at an arbitrary place. A final bookish touch in both manuscripts is to number the lines by fives in the left margin.
How much time divides these closely related bookish treatments of the longer poems from the earlier 1827 lyric—descriptive poems? The “Constellations”, RF T70, and “Monastery”, 1–2, can be triangulated with a third fair copy, that of “Eudosia”, which is dated by Ruskin as 28 September 1828. Here, too, are found the miniscule lettering, the punctuation ending each line until it doesnʼt, and the line numbering on the left. Thus, these ambitious (and inevitably incomplete) projects—a versified novel, a catalogue of the constellations, and “a poem on the universe”—belong to 1828, although perhaps not all three to the final third of the year. This was the year of the Ruskinsʼ aborted spring Tour of 1828, which was cut short by the death of Jessie Richardson, and followed by a period of mourning, and the resettlement of her children, including the adoption of Mary Richardson into the Herne Hill household.
here
More speculatively, one might order the three works chronologically according to skill. “Eudosia” is perhaps the earliest, since it frequently exhibits a bizarre mark made of two dots, like a colon on its side or a two—point ellipsis. This mark does not appear in “The Monastery”, where all the colons are right—side up, although the semicolons are upside—down, with the comma atop the point. “The Constellations” exhibits no incorrectly formed marks, though only twenty lines carry any punctuation at all. Still, this correctness, combined with the prominence
of poetry densely at the start of the poem, but abandoned punctuation later. Since the , suggesting that Ruskin gradually lost interest in that feature of the fair copy; and in both, the punctuation is eccentric, his use of colons seeming more decorative than functional, although his rhetorical use of commas and periods seems marginally more coherent in the opening lines of the RF T70 “Constellations” as compared with the opening lines of the MS III “Monastery”. Presumably, though not certainly, Ruskin made these revisions shortly before fair—copying the revised text in MS III, perhaps in late 1827—early 1828.
In fact, the original fair copy in RF T70, and not just its revisions, may have only shortly predated the MS III version—or at least the second page of the fair copy may have been significantly closer in time to the revisions. Starting at line 53 of RF T70, the fair‐copy hand suddenly appears larger, and Ruskin abandons the line numbering in the margin—suggestions perhaps that, at this point, Ruskin may already have decided to sacrifice this fair copy to revision (see also textual note for line 54).

div.head: Print Sources
div.p: One verifiable source of Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations is revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues. In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. He points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and describes the formation using the diagram—four stars forming a waggon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear or Ursa Major. This constellation, he explains, can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define east and west. As a northern, circumpolar constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it points to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) if one traces a line upward through the two stars forming the rear end of the waggon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 12–18, 250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]).

In Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank: A Sequel the Engineer marks passages in the Scientific Dialogues where Frank can find information about astronomy. Frank, in turn, recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of the moor by the help of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, the tutor, Mr. Barlow, cites Harryʼs story of self‐preservation as an instance of practical uses to be derived from scientific understanding, an emphasis likewise imparted but with more detailed and sophisticated scientific information by the Tutor in Scientific Dialogues.

In Sandford and Merton, Tommy ensures they can find Charlesʼ Wain again by diagramming the stars on paper, and he carries on to conceive of a celestial globe in order to map all the constellations. Mr. Barlow obliges with a paper‐covered ball on which the boys can record their own observations of the constellations. While the emphasis is on practical and scientific knowledge, Mr. Barlow also encourages appreciation of natural beauty:

Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)

The poem “The Constellations” is Ruskinʼs answer to to putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem, along with Harryʼs drawing, effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of Ruskinʼs reading about astronomy, the poemʼs seemingly mechanical exercise of listing the star clusters carries out the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [forming Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs Charles and James in the names and positions of the constellations.

In his poem, Ruskin adopts the tactic of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs tutors by starting from a prominent point of reference—not, in Ruskinʼs case, a constellation, but a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, a wandering rather than a fixed star. In this instance, Venus is associated with the constellation Orion as these bodies fall below the horizon in the west, and then the poem re‐orients to the circumpolar constellations overhead After this, Ruskin carries on to list the formations supposedly in a sequence, the lines of the poem clicking along by repeating “next”; however, the organization, although not without logic, becomes more erratic (see Real‐life Observations).

Neither Joyceʼs nor Dayʼs books lists all the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem. For most of the constellation names and mythological associations, he used a source that remains to be identified. In the editorial glosses to the poem, some connections are made with books known to have been owned by the family; for the present, the mythology associated with the constellations is glossed using an American text of the period, Astronomical Recreations (1824) by Green, along with modern reference works.

div.head: The Context of Astromical Practice and Instruction in Early Victorian Britain
div.p: It is possible that Ruskin produced this poem by relying entirely on print sources. Despite the simplicity and even numbingly repetitive structure of its verse catalogue of names, however, the poem prompts significant questions about the context of scientific education in which it was produced. Did Ruskin engage in actual stargazing as preparation for any part of the poem. Does the poem reflect conditions of British astronomoical practice and education in the 1820s? Evidence is limited, but the introduction to astronomy provided by Ruskinʼs familiar scientific dialogues by Joyce, Day, and Edgeworth could have not have sustained this poem beyond its opening dozen or so lines.

div.head: Observations Actual and Poetic
div.p: As indicated by Ruskinʼs sources, “The Constellations” is a bookish poem. Even in Ruskinʼs books, however, tutors begin study of astronomy by directing their pupilsʼ attention to the evening sky. To what extent, if any, might Ruskinʼs composition of his poem have involved actual observation? Ruskin opens his poem by hailing Venus and Mars. Planets are not an obvious starting point for charting the constellations: tutors in Ruskinʼs books typically begin by asking pupils to find Charlesʼs Wain. Nonetheless, Venus as the Morning Star or Evening Star and Mars as the red planet present striking objects to introduce young people to stargazing. Incidentally, the evidence might lend support to dating of the poem.

In the poem. Ruskin positions Venus specifically as the Evening Star near the constellation Orion. According to a digital‐age star chart, the Sky & Telescope Interactive Sky Chart, Venus would have been visible from London as the Evening Star, setting in the west along with Orionm during April‐June 1828. During those same months, Mars would have risen from the east, traveling “high . . . [in] the sky” a few hours after Venus had set.

This particular configuration of Venus, Mars, and Orion did not appear at any other time in 1828, and did not occur at all in 1827. Astronomically, then, the introduction aligns with the evidence in Composition and Publication supporting the year 1828 as the probable period of composition. April–May was the period when he tyically prepared poems for his fatherʼs birthday in May, thus suggesting at least an occasion as well as a terminus a quo for the start of composition on “The Constellations” (Sky & Telescope, Interactive Star Chart and Celestial Almanac, accessed 12 April 2023). This convergence of evidence enables us to imagine also that Ruskin looked up from his books to the sky for a phenomenon with which to open his poem.

Even so, that search for Orion was likely inspired by Tommy Merton, who, “looking up to the sky . . . observed so remarkable a constellation, that he . . . begged to know the name”. On learning it was called Orion, he “was so delighted with the grandeur and beauty of this glorious constellation, that he could not help observing it, by intervals, all the evening; and he was surprised to see that it seemed to pass on, in a right line drawn from east to west; and that all the stars he had become acquainted with moved every night in the same direction”. In the opening four lines of the poem, Ruskin echoes the alliterative modifiers with which Mr. Barlow describes the experience of gazing at the constellations: “‘I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us’” (Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 187–88, 165 [emphasis added]).

The bodies above that were visible at all times of the year to British youth were the circumpolar constellations—the “northern” constellations, as Ruskin specified among the classifications tagged onto his main title. Of the constellations named in lines 7–11 of Ruskinʼs poem, only Charlesʼs Wain is mentioned by the Tutors in Dayʼs and Joyceʼs dialogues. An observer in April 1828, however, could easily have followed Ruskinʼs cues by looking up from Orion setting in the west to trace the poemʼs network of constellations overhead. Locating Ursa Major (the Great Bear) in the center of the sky, the observer would find the “pointer” stars embedded in Charlesʼs Wain (which forms part of Ursa Major), using these to trace a path to the tip of Draco (the Dragon)ʼs tail. Following the wind of the tail toward the northeast, the observer would turn to the east to encounter Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown). Continuing to circle counter—clockwise back toward Ursa Major, the observer would have found the next named constellation in the poem, Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair).

div.head: Names versus Numbers: The Mythology of the Constellations and Modern Astronomy
div.p: Hereafter in Ruskinʼs poem, following the mapping of some connected circumpolar constellations, the sequence of constellations becomes more erratic, with Ruskinʼs repeated “next comes” ceasing necessarily to refer to formations that are adjacent in the dome of the sky. The poem is interested more in naming than in mapping, identifying the mythological figures, beasts, and objects associated with the constellations, although not pausing to narrate those myths. The poem becomes a catalogue, not a narrative.

Ruskinʼs engagement with the mythic names and poetic images associated with the constellations sets his poem apart from Joyceʼs dialogues on astronomy, in which the Tutor and his scholars, while ready to quote illustrative poetry, are dismissive of the mythology:

James. ‘Why are the signs of the Zodiac called by the several names of Aries, Taurus, Leo, &c. I see no likeness in the heavens to Rams, or Bulls, or Lions, which are the English words for those Latin ones”;.
Tutor. “Nor do I.”
(Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 4, “Of the Ephemeris”, 2:36–37).

Instead of myths, the lesson that Joyceʼs Tutor dwells on is the arbitrariness underlying the naming systems of astronomy. The imagined patterns in the sky whereby the ancients ordered and named the constellations, the Tutor emphasizes, were arbitrary constructions:

Tutor. “The ancients, that they might the better distinguish and describe the stars, with regard to their situation in the heavens, divided them into constellations, that is, systems of stars, each system consisting of such stars as were near to each other, giving them the names of such men or things, as they fancied the space which they occupied in the heavens represented”.
Charles“It is then perfectly arbitrary, that one collection is called the great bear, another the dragon; a third Hercules, and so on”.
(Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 13–14).

The arbitrariness of naming extends beyond the ancient constellations to modern systems: “‘If you look on the [celestial] globe’”, the Tutor continues, “‘you will observe, that . . . [lesser stars] are distinguished by the different letters of the Greek alphabet’”, which are also assigned arbitrarily (Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 3, “Of the Fixed Stars, and Ecliptic”, 23). As a more sophisticated system, the Tutor leads his pupils from the diagram of Charlesʼs Wain to a celestial globe, which he uses to orient the constellations to the ecliptic and equator; and then he directs the boys to an ephemeris, a catalogue of star positions (Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversations 2–4, 12–47). Modern ephemerides were based on exacting observations and mathematical computations, which were the pride of scientifically advanced nations that produced these star catalogues. It has been argued, however, that their forbidding tables made the ephemerides a “primary culprit” in driving away public interest in astronomy, displacing the appeal to popular imagination that the stars had presented in the annual almanacs with a professionalization of the science that seemed inaccessible to omateur “sky‐loving men”, in Ruskinʼs phrase (Donnelly, “On the Boredom of Science”, 493–97).

As a less exacting task, Dayʼs Mr. Barlow contrives a paper globe on which Tommy and Harry can draw the constellations (The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, 187). Ruskinʼs poem perhaps works like an ersatz globe, listing constellation names in a sequence that oscillates back and forth from west to east and back again, or that possibly circles counter—clockwise—a pattern, if he intended any pattern at all, that Ruskin could have plotted only by referencing a celestial globe or illustrated star charts in a book.

At line 12, following the circumpolar constellations, the next listed constellation is Cygnus (the Swan). Assuming, for consistencyʼs sake, the hour of Orionʼs setting in the west in April 1828, Cygnus would have lain on the northeast horizon, beyond Draco. Then the following item, Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart) would have directed the viewer back toward the center of the dome, within Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs), between Ursa Major and Coma Berenices. For the next, the now obsolete constellation, Herschellʼs Telescope, one would have turned back toward the west, where it would have been rising as Orion was setting, located within Auriga (the Charioteer). The next, Equuleus (Little Horse), is found between Pegasus and Delphinus, which would have lain back toward Cygnus, rising on the northeast horizon as the evening advanced on April 28. The next named constellation, the Goose (Anser), does keep within range of Equuleus; however, to get from Goose to Hare—Anser to Lepus (hare)—again sends one in the opposite direction, to the feet of Orion.

At this point in the RF T70 draft, Ruskin originally cited Lyra (the Lyre), which he replaced with Lepus (Hare). Since Lyra is found in the same quadrant as Anser and Cygnus, by substituting Hare, which lies at Orionʼs feet, Ruskin maintained a pattern of back—and—forth, west—to—east and back again (or counter—clockwise circling), but in naming Hare he also dropped below the celestial equator to “some of the southern” constellations, as his title mentions. A few lines later, he will plunge into the corresponding southern constellations on the opposite side with Crux (Southern Cross). It seems to break the pattern that, intervening between these southern constellations, Ruskin lists Ursa Minor (Lesser Bear), which contains the Pole Star, but perhaps he paused midway across the sky only to rhyme hare and bear. He may also have wanted Ursa Minor. to stand as a barrier between Anser, “stupid goose”, and “cunning fox” (Vulpecula), which follows Ursa Minor in the list. Traditionally, Fox and Goose were treated as a single constellation, Vulpecula et Anser, with the Goose caught in the Foxʼs mouth (Ridpath, Star Tales, 182–83). By separating them, Ruskin characteristically avoided violence.

div.head: The Lenten Astronomy Lecture
div.p: After , Ruskin arrives at the Zodiac, as also mentioned in his title, which may hint at another context for his interest in astronomy. As a distinct activity from professional astronomy with its mathematical orientation combined with observation—the less popularly accessible approach, which Joyceʼs Tutor encourages over the mythological tradition—there thrived in the 1820s a popular form of astronomy education, which combined technology with art, modern science with traditional elements such as the Zodiac. The popular astronomy lecture was a theatrical entertainment, commonly known as Lenten astronomy lectures since they could be held in London theaters during the holy season, when plays were forbidden. The timing of these spectacles fits with the proposed April–June 1828 period for composition of “The Constellations”, which might have been initiated by attendance at a lecture. (In 1828, Easter Day fell on 6 April. John James Ruskinʼs accounts for April 1828 include “Abernethys Lectrs” for 12s, but this entry probably refers to published lectures by the surgeon, John Abernethy [1764–1831]; Account Book, 6r).

The astronomy lecture circuit—originating in the late eighteenth century, becoming a craze in the 1820s, and remaining a staple of popular science instruction at least until mid—century—has been researched by Hsiang—Fu Huang, who finds that its performative and entrepreneurial aspects overlapped with the insitutional framework of lecturing that was supposedly displacing these popular forms of instruction in the 1820s (Huang, “A Shared Arena”). A target audience for the lectures included children, as Huang notes (“When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 60–61), astronomy being regarded as an uplifting area of knowledge religiously as well as scientifically. As a guidebook of London amusements solemnly assured parents about the content of Lenten astronomy lectures—even as performed by George Bartley (1784–1858), who was not a scientist but a comic actor, famed for his portrayals of Shakespeareʼs Falstaff—the spectacle would convey “to the minds of their children the lofty and magnificent ideas that Astronomy supplies”—namely,

Beauty, Order, and Sublimity in the Heavens, [which] appear to their expanding intellect, in all their delightful prospects; and the feelings, that will certainly influence their entrée into life, will be characterized by a marked reverence for that “Divinity which breathes within us, / And points out an after state to man”. Adults, as well as children, will derive, from this exhibition, an increased perception of the power, dignity, and ubiquity, of that Being whom we ought to serve.
(Wellbeloved, London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 4; on Bartley, see Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 54–57)

Even as educational entertainments for children, however, the Lenten astronomy lectures were regarded with some criticism by educators, as Ruskin would have known from Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank. After Frank has attempted and failed on his own to construct an orrery, a model of the solar system, his parents take him and his cousin Mary to an astronomy lecture at a theater. The performance features something like the large—scale, illuminated or “transparent” stage orreries with Greek—inspired names like Eidouranion, which combined the older mechanical, three—dimensional orrery that reproduced the revolutions of the sun and planets with transparancies projected by a magic lantern (see Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 49–51, 66 n. 23). For Edgeworth, criticism of these spectacles pertains not just to quack lecturers and creaky, dysfunctional orreries, which Huang finds in satires of the day (“When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 62–63); more fundamentally, Edgeworth points to conflicts with reformersʼ principles of effective pedagogy.

The theatrical spectacle is a grand but passive presentation, discouraging learning through experience and self—discovery. Even though Frank had failed to complete his own orrery because he over—reached his abilities, the stage orrery is “particularly interesting to Frank” thanks only to “the pains he had taken, and the various attempts he had made, to understand and to represent” the revolving bodies. The other “little children” in the audience went “dead asleep” and “even he”, Frank, “after all his reading in Scientific Dialogues, had much difficulty sometimes in understanding both the machine and the lecturer”. Edgeworthʼs most severe criticism is aimed at the failure to scale knowledge to the age—appropriate accessibility of young listeners. The lecturer overwhelms the audience “with a vast number of words, which” Frank “strained his attention” to understand, trusting that the lengthy explanations “were all necessary”, yet “of which nearly half were nothing to the purpose” and put Mary to sleep altogether. As for the London guidebookʼs promise of the theatrical augmentation of Beauty, Order, and Sublimity, it is the sight of the real moon on the ride home that prompts a spontaneous reaction from Mary: “‘How beautiful!’ said she: ‘and how—’ sublime! she would have said, but she did not know the word well enough: she knew the feeling.” Feelings are represented as accessible, regardless of age and learning; and despite Edgeworthʼs promotion of the Industrial Sublime in Harry and Lucy Concluded, here Frank responds to Maryʼs admiration: “How wonderful! What is the orrery compared to this, Mary! . . . How grand! how different from any thing that the most ingenious man in this world can make!” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:251, 253, 255, 249, 256, 257).

The opposite effect on children was promised by promoters of astronomy as a theatrical spectacle: astronomical science in particular, it was argued, benefits by the intervention of art. According to the 1826 guidebook, astronomy lectures are the epitome science enhanced of metropolitan “improvements and amusements”:

Astronomy, universally acknowledged the most sublime and interesting of those sciences which admit of popular illustration, is doubly valuable for its powerful influence and effect in the general improvement of the human mind. . . . {T}he science of astronomy is . . . the very science of which a popular display may most successfully be aided by the ornamental arts. Music, painting, sculpture, may be called in as auxiliaries, with powerful effect, and manifest benefit; a tasteful introduction of poetry may be deemed almost essential to success; and we would undertake that Urania need not disdain the co—operation of Terpsichore herself.
(Wellbeloved, London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 3; see Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 47)

Wellbeloved devotes two pages describing in detail how a new “hydraulic” orrery has improved on older “instruments . . . hitherto . . . constructed by a complication of wheel—work, which, although extremely ingenious, are nevertheless almost unequal to the imitation of those equable, silent, and undeviating movements, which characterize the grandest works of the Creator”. Yet, despite the interest the reader is assumed to take in two close pages of technical description of how hydraulic improvements have brought the orrery closer to the operations of the Creator, the accompanying engraving sets the machine in a “design of our own”—a moonlit natural landscape like the scene that impresses Mary and Frank as tending to the disadvantage of technology (London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 6–7).

Despite these conflicts with the Edgeworthian basis of Ruskinʼs education, some elements of the Lenten lectures correspond to Ruskinʼs poem. The lectures appear to have presented a somewhat uniform set of topics. In Edgeworthʼs fictional treatment, the topics resemble those listed in An Epitome of Astronomy . . . as Illustrated by the Eidouranion, a pamphlet published to accompany lectures by the Walker family, first published in 1782 and here quoted from the edition of 1812:

list.item:
Scene 1. “The Sun and Earth: with the Zodiacal Constellations” (p. 6).
“This scene is surrounded by transparent paintings of the twelve signs of the Zodiac, shewing how the Sun, or rather the Earth, enters and passes through Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, &c.” (p. 8).
Scene 2. “Sun, Earth, and Moon: Phases and Eclipses” (p. 9).

Scene 3. “Theory of Tides” (p. 13)
In Frank: A Sequel, “By this time the lecturer had come to an explanation of the cause of the tides, which neither Mary nor Frank could comprehend. His father judiciously and kindly took them out to rest their attention, and refresh themselves while this lasted. They went into a cool room, where they eat oranges and biscuits, and drank lemonade, till the tides were over” (2:252).
Scene 4. “The Solar System” (p. 16), including “Four New Planets” (p. 23) and “Comets” (p. 29).

Last Scene. This final scene is not announced in the pamphlet by a separate heading, as is the case with the four preceding scenes, but embedded in a peroration on the infinitude of the universe: “. . . how in adequate must the utmost stretch of finite faculties be to represent infinity! The stars, disposed in constellations, and surrounded by concentric circles, may perhaps assist the imagination a little: The attempt in the LAST SCENE, if not admired, we hope will be forgiven. But was it possible we could actually take our flight into infinite space, or be borne on the wings of lightning, to the most distant fixed Star we can now see, even there, perhaps we should find ourselves on the confines of creation, and see as many stars before us as we left behind! For space has neither top nor bottom in it; it is a circle whose centre is every where, but whose circumference is no where!” (pp. 36–37).

div.p: According to this description, the “Last Scene”, at least as delivered by the Walker family, which by 1828 had passed into the management of Deane Franklin Walker (1778–1865 [Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 50]), the most comprehensive view of the constellations was presented as the finale. Could Ruskin have conceived of his poem as an ekphrastic version of this final, totalizing scene? Apparently, in this show, a transparency exhibited a circle of the starry night, surrounded by concentric rings to suggest infinitude. In an engraving by I. Stow (ca. 1770–1823), after E. F. Burney (1760–1848), The proscenium of the English Opera House in the Strand, (Late Lyceum.) as it appeared on the Evening of the 21st March 1817, with Walkerʼs Exhibition of the Eidouranion, published by Robert Wilkinson, Scene 1 represented the earth and sun by turning the orbit vertically to the audience, enclosing this revolution of the Eidouranion within a projection of an outer ring, which showed the Zodiac constellations. The Zodiac constellations were represented by their respective mythological figures. Perhaps the transparency for the Last Scene exhibited a similar ring of constellations in their mythological guise, which Ruskin in his way has reproduced.

The beginning of the poem, however, starts with a version of Scene 1 in the Walkersʼ exhibition—or more precisely, a portion of their Scene 4—with the rising and setting of Venus and Mars. As noted earlier, the poem is atypical of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs introductions to the constellations, which begin with finding the circumpolar constellations in the sky. Ruskin incorporates that observation as the second stage of his poem. The Zodiac constellations form a distinct piece within the poem. The most significant point to draw from the context of the Lenten astronomy lectures is that Ruskinʼs catalogue may have attempted a sublime totality, an expression of religious awe.
